item.title: Categories and modalities for smoothness
item.description:
Smoothness

Greg Langmead
  • 1 Introduction
  • 2 Sheaves on CartSp
  • 3 The algebra of functions
  • 4 The lemmas about smoothness
  • 5 Nilpotents
  • 6 The Kan extention
  • 7 The modality

1 Introduction

As someone ‚Äúclassically trained‚Äù in differential geometry, my recent adventures in homotopy type theory have made me very excited to explore an entirely new angle on a topic I love. It is the case today that modal HoTT allows us to access smoothness and prove theorems about manifolds, Lie groups and more. In order to participate in this new and exciting field, someone like me needs a bridge. More than one, in fact. The current document is intended as one of those bridges. Starting from the classical definition of a smooth manifold and the category containing these objects and the smooth maps between them, we will define several enlargements of the category until we arrive at something where modal HoTT can be interpreted.

To make the most of this process, we will always try to keep track of where smoothness is entering in. It‚Äôs not always obvious!

Definition 1.

A smooth manifold is a Hausdorff topological space M with countable basis, and with a maximal smooth atlas. An atlas is a covering of M by open sets Ui, each of which is the image of a homeomorphism fi:Rn‚ÜíM (called a chart), such that fj-1‚àòfi is smooth wherever it is defined. Two atlases are compatible if their union is again an atlas. The maximal atlas is the union of all compatible atlases.

Note that this definition expresses M as a colimit of a diagram of arrows from ‚Ñùn‚ÜíM, more specifically a pushout. More on this shortly.

A continuous function f:M‚ÜíN between two smooth manifolds is defined to be smooth if the appropriate composition with charts is a smooth function between cartesian spaces.

The category SmoothMfd¬†has objects the smooth manifolds of any finite dimension, and morphisms the smooth maps.

This category, innocuous though it seems, has some strange properties! There are topological manifolds that are missing from it, and some that are way over-represented! You can‚Äôt just take a topological manifold and assume you can give it a unique maximal smooth atlas and stick it into SmoothMfd.

The table below contains some examples.

kind of manifold number of inequivalent smooth atlases
dim ‚â§3 1
dim ‚â•5 ‚â•0, finite
‚Ñùn,n‚â†4 1
‚Ñù4 uncountably many
S4 unknown, ‚â•1
dim =4, compact without boundary ‚â•0, at most countably many
dim =4, otherwise ‚â•1, at most uncountably many

The claim that S4 has exactly one smooth structure is known as the four-dimensional smooth Poincar√© conjecture. Its status is ‚Äúextremely unknown‚Äù. For more of the beautiful story around low-dimensional topology and smooth structures see Scorpan [7].

The spheres behave surprisingly as well.

n number of inequivalent smooth atlases on Sn
1 1
2 1
3 1
4 ‚â•1
5 1
6 1
7 28
8 2
9 8
10 6
11 992
12 1
13 3
14 2
15 16256
16 2
17 16
18 16
19 523264
20 24

(from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_structure)

Is SmoothMfd¬†a nice category? It is closed under finite products and coproducts. Manifolds are themselves certain colimits. However in general this category has neither limits nor colimits. Nor is it cartesian closed.

For example, consider the equalizer {(x,y)|x‚Å¢y=0}‚äÇ‚Ñù2. As a set this must be equal to the union of the x-axis and y-axis. But this cannot be given the structure of a topological manifold nor a smooth one, due to the failure to be homeomorphic to any ‚Ñùn at the origin. Full argument: the forgetful functor U:ùñ≤ùóÜùóàùóàùóçùóÅùñ¨ùñøùñΩ‚Üíùñ≤ùñæùóç preserves limits and colimits as it has both left and right adjoints. The equalizer as a set is this union of axes, and so the manifold must have that underlying set. But this set cannot be promoted to a smooth manifold.

Consider the coequalizer (‚Ñù2‚Å¢‚àê‚Ñù)/(0,0)‚àº0. Similarly this cannot be given the structure of a topological manifold nor a smooth one, also at the origin.

Is SmoothMfd¬†cartesian closed, i.e. does it contain function spaces of smooth maps? This has been attempted with some success, but we‚Äôll skip over that story because we‚Äôre going to do it with sheaves later. In fact right now.

2 Sheaves on CartSp

My take on presheaves and sheaves is inspired by Daniel Dugger‚Äôs informal notes Sheaves and Homotopy Theory[3]. His analogy to generators and relations is the one that clicked for me in this context.

Define CartSp¬†to be the full subcategory of SmoothMfd¬†containing just the ‚Ñùn for finite n (recall that ‚Äúfull‚Äù means include every morphism). In the case of ‚Ñù4 let‚Äôs just bring the standard smooth structure. We can try to build the fake ‚Ñù4s later on with surgery and such.

Due to the existence of real-valued functions such as 11+e-x we can map all of ‚Ñù¬†to the open interval (0,1). So note that this category is not as pitifully empty as I, at least, thought at first. You can cover ‚Ñùn with balls each of which is a diffeomorphic image of ‚Ñùn. We‚Äôll be doing just that.

To generalize SmoothMfd¬†we‚Äôll use CartSp¬†in a new way. In the original definition of a smooth manifold we captured the concept of ‚Äúmodeled on ‚Ñùn‚Äù in a definition we can summarize as ‚Äúis locally isomorphic to ‚Ñùn.‚Äù But we will now shift to a definition like ‚Äúcan be probed by ‚Ñùn‚Äù or ‚Äúhas specified maps from the test spaces ‚Ñùn.‚Äù

A presheaf on CartSp¬†is a functor

ùñ¢ùñ∫ùóãùóçùñ≤ùóâop‚ÜíSet

Think of one presheaf M (suggestive name) as a would-be space together with the specification of what probing functions are smooth. Sometimes these probes are called plots. These are different from charts. Charts are specific homeomorphisms that cover M. Here we must provide the entire set of all possible smooth functions into M from ‚Ñùn, for all n.

The category Psh(CartSp)¬†consists of all such functors, together with the natural transformations between them. This is an interesting category! If C is any locally small category, there is an embedding (a full and faithful functor that is injective on objects) C‚ÜíùñØùóåùóÅ‚Å¢(C) called the Yoneda embedding. In fact Psh(C) is the free cocompletion of C, meaning it freely adds all colimits from C. In fact Psh(C) is a topos which is a checklist of wonderful properties, and we‚Äôll be using them all by the end because HoTT and toposes are closely related. In a nutshell, Psh(C) inherits these nice properties from ùñ≤ùñæùóç.

BUT.

If C already has some colimits, Psh(C) will not respect these. It is too free.

Consider two subobjects of ‚Ñùn in CartSp, say two disjoint open balls U and V.

Following Duggers we think of sheaves as the subcategory of presheaves that preserve the existing colimits that we had. There is an analogy to specifying a group as the quotient of a free group by a subgroup generated by some relations.

It‚Äôs illustrative to understand the layers of exoticness that are introduced by moving from SmoothMfd¬†to sheaves. Manifolds embed in diffeological spaces which are the concrete sheaves (see Baez and Hoffnung [2]).

3 The algebra of functions

For a smooth manifold M the set of smooth real-valued maps f:M‚Üí‚Ñù has the structure of a vector space, a ring, and in fact a commutative algebra. An algebra is a vector space over a base field (hence it has a commutative addition operation) which also has a multiplication operation that satisfies the distributive law when it interacts with addition. If the multiplication is commutative then we say the algebra is commutative. In this case the operations are all pointwise and so inherited from ‚Ñù. For example f‚Å¢g‚Å¢(x)=f‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢g‚Å¢(x) where the right hand side is multiplication in ‚Ñù.

Proposition 1.

Taking the algebra C‚àû‚Å¢(M) of smooth functions of a smooth manifold M gives a functor ùñ≤ùóÜùóàùóàùóçùóÅùñ¨ùñøùñΩ‚ÜíC‚àûùñ¢ùñ†ùóÖùóÄR.

There are important subcategories of ùñ¢ùñ†ùóÖùóÄ‚Ñù that themselves contain the image of this functor, notably the ‚Äúsmooth algebras‚Äù but we won‚Äôt make use of their special properties, so we might as well use the simpler larger category.

Crucially this functor is actually faithful, meaning if you fix two manifolds then the functor is injective on the hom set between them. Said another way, any algebra homomorphism C‚àû‚Å¢(N)‚ÜíC‚àû‚Å¢(M) comes from a smooth map M‚ÜíN. Therefore we can embed SmoothMfd¬†into ùñ¢ùñ†ùóÖùóÄ‚Ñù and treat its image as an equivalent copy of SmoothMfd¬†and find new ways to extend it and build new categories!

The proof of faithfulness is interesting and we will explore it fully because it‚Äôs challenging to piece it together from the references that exist easily to hand today. Since we have a couple other such ‚Äúsmooth facts‚Äù to make use of let‚Äôs handle them together.

4 The lemmas about smoothness

Lemma 1.

(‚ÄúMilnor‚Äôs Exercise‚Äù) The map M‚ÜíevHom‚Å¢(C‚àû‚Å¢(M),R)=Hom‚Å¢(C‚àû‚Å¢(M),C‚àû‚Å¢(R0)) given by evaluation at a point of M is a bijection.

Proof.

See also Kol√°≈ô, Michor and Slov√°k [5], especially the preamble before section 35 and Corollary 35.9. ‚àé

It is perhaps notable that there is a larger class of topological manifolds for which Milnor‚Äôs exercise holds, which goes by the name realcompact.

Lemma 2.

For two smooth manifolds M1 and M2 the map

C‚àû‚Å¢(M1,M2) ‚ÜíHom‚Å¢(C‚àû‚Å¢(M2),C‚àû‚Å¢(M1)) (1)
f ‚Ü¶(g‚Ü¶g‚àòf) (2)

given by precomposition is a bijection, i.e. ùñ≤ùóÜùóàùóàùóçùóÅùñ¨ùñøùñΩ‚ÜíC‚àûùñ¢ùñ†ùóÖùóÄR is faithful.

Lemma 3.

(Hadamard) If f:Rn‚ÜíR is smooth then in some open neighborhood U‚äá(0,‚Ä¶,0)

f‚Å¢(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)=f‚Å¢(0)+‚àëi=1nxi‚Å¢gi‚Å¢(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)

for smooth functions gi satisfying

g‚Å¢(0,‚Ä¶,0)=‚àÇ‚Å°f‚àÇ‚Å°xi‚Å¢(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)|(0,‚Ä¶,0)
Lemma 4.

Hom‚Å¢(C‚àû‚Å¢(M),‚Ñù‚Å¢[x]/x2) is in bijection with T‚Å¢M, the tangent bundle of M.

5 Nilpotents

How the power is about the jet degree and the number of variables is about the dimension of the probing vector space. Remember 1?

6 The Kan extention

For an elementary introduction to the adjunctions we are discussing between presheaf categories see Awodey [1].

7 The modality

Differential cohesion is most gently introduced by Khavkine and Schreiber in [4] and plays a large role in Schreiber‚Äôs magnum opus [6].

References

  • [3] D. Dugger (1999) Sheaves and Homotopy Theory. (en). External Links: Link Cited by: ¬ß2.
  • [4] I. Khavkine and U. Schreiber (2017-01) Synthetic geometry of differential equations: I. Jets and comonad structure. (en). External Links: Link Cited by: ¬ß7.
  • [5] I. Kol√°≈ô, P. W. Michor and J. Slov√°k (1993-01) Natural Operations in Differential Geometry. 1993 edition edition, Springer, Berlin ; New York (English). External Links: ISBN 978-3-540-56235-1 Cited by: ¬ß4.
  • [6] U. Schreiber (2013-10) Differential cohomology in a cohesive infinity-topos. (en). External Links: Link Cited by: ¬ß7.
